content:
Hi,

I've been struggling a bit to figure out exactly what category I'm in for a problem I'm working on. I should end up in a category whose objects are bimodules and morphisms are bimodule homomorphisms. The catch is that I want to freely construct this functorially starting with a directed graph.

A directed graph is often defined as a functor

G:X→Set,G: X\to\mathsf{Set},G:X→Set,

where XXX is a category with two objects X0,X1X^0,X^1X0,X1 and two morphisms s,t:X1→X0.s,t: X^1\to X^0.s,t:X1→X0. This doesn't work for me because I don't see any way that s,ts,ts,t can map to bimodule homomorphisms.

I just had a thought :light_bulb:

What if instead, we defined a directed graph as a functor

G:I→Span1(Set)G: I\to\mathsf{Span_1(Set)}G:I→Span1​(Set)

from the interval category III with two objects 0,10,10,1 and 1 non-identity morphism 0→10\to 10→1.

This would map

0↦G00\mapsto G^00↦G0

1↦G11\mapsto G^11↦G1

and the one morphism maps to the span

G0←G1→G0.G^0\leftarrow G^1\rightarrow G^0.G0←G1→G0.

This plays nicer with my bimodule category because that morphism as a span maps to a bimodule morphism.

Is that crazy?
It feels correct
Yeah. Same here. Composing that morphism with itself nnn times generates [Edit: consists of] paths of length nnn.
What do you mean by 'composing'?
Oh I see. You can compose G(0→1)G(0 \to 1)G(0→1) with itself as spans
I mean the usual composition of spans via pullback.
Yeah
G1⊗G0G1G^1\otimes_{G^0} G^1G1⊗G0​G1 consists of paths of length 2.
This feels nice :+1:

Functors from the interval category classify morphisms, so if Span1(Set)\mathsf{Span}_1(\mathsf{Set})Span1​(Set) is the category whose objects are sets and morphisms spans of sets, then a functor from III is a span between two possibly different sets. Rather it's endomorphisms that correspond to directed graphs.
The “classifier for endomorphisms” would be the monoid N\mathbb{N}N. Maybe that's what you want.

Then, yeah, a functor N→Span1(Set)\mathbb{N} \to \mathsf{Span}_1(\mathsf{Set})N→Span1​(Set) is determined by what the image of 111 is, and that's a directed graph. The image of nnn is the directed graph whose edges are length-nnn paths in the image of 111.

Eric wrote:

I should end up in a category whose objects are bimodules and morphisms are bimodule homomorphisms.

Bimodules of some particular specified algebra(s) that you're not telling us?
People don't usually say things like what you just said: they might say "a category whose objects are (A,B)-bimodules and whose morphisms are bimodule homomorphisms" for some algebras A and B...
or if A = B, you might say "(A,A)-bimodules" or maybe "A-bimodules".

I just feel like adding that there's a super-important bicategory where:

  • objects are algebras over some field k,
  • morphisms from A to B are (A,B)-bimodules,
  • 2-morphisms are bimodule homomorphisms.

So here we aren't choosing a particular A and B: we're choosing all of them!
Is that part of a framed bicategory, even?
Yes! These days the politically correct term is "fibrant double category".
So there are three different names now?
What's the third one?
Proarrow equipment.
Oh, right! I knew that.

"Framed bicategory" was deprecated by topologists, who use "framed" to mean "equipped with a trivialization of the normal bundle" - and @Mike Shulman's original work at this was aimed to some extent at homotopy theorists (like his thesis advisor).
Since it's a kind of double category it probably does make sense to call it a ".... double category".
"Proarrow equipment" has its own advantages but it really brings a completely different set of mental associations to mind: it makes me feel like I'm generalizing Cat\mathbf{Cat}Cat and profunctors!
In my work on network theory I say "fibrant double category".
In those applications the "proarrows" are the guys you really focus on: they're the "open systems".
Yeah. The 'proarrow' mindset seems like it probably has plenty of examples, though. Like various combinations of homomorphisms and 'relations' into a single category

Of course, "fibrant double category" is not without its own problems. For instance, the category of double categories admits at least half a dozen different model structures, and as far as I know these are not the fibrant objects in any of them!
Where is the quote from, by the way? nlab's "fibrant double category" just links to framed bicategory.
Oh, I guess it wasn't a direct quote of anyone?
I think John probably meant to say "framed bicategory" -- I haven't heard anyone say "framed double category" except by accident.
I think I just saw fewer quotation marks than are there, so thought he was quoting something about topologists not liking "framed bicategory".

When I said

"Framed double category" was deprecated by topologists,...

I meant

"Framed bicategory" was deprecated by topologists,...

That was me talking.
And yeah, I kinda hate how "fibrant double categories" aren't fibrant objects in some famous model structure on some category of double categories.
If it weren't so long I'd probably say something like "double categories with twistable arrows".
Where does the name come from? Are the objects of the double category somehow considered to be fibrant? Like, is the promotion of an arrow to a proarrow like a lifting property?
The name comes from @Mike Shulman, so I'll let him answer that!

Good morning :coffee:

Thank you Matteo. Thank you Amar. Thank you (as always) John :raised_hands:

Although I feel I am on the right track, I woke up thinking "Oops!". A functor F:I→CF: I\to CF:I→C maps to two objects F(0)F(0)F(0), F(1)F(1)F(1) in CCC and one morphism F(0)→F(1)F(0)\to F(1)F(0)→F(1) in CCC. That isn't what I want :thinking: So I am happy to see some corrections / help :santa: :pray:

I woke up not in despair though because I thought I could fix it by considering, instead of III, a category XXX with two objects X0X^0X0,X1X^1X1 and one morphism being a span X0←sX1→tX0X^0\overset{s}{\leftarrow} X^1\overset{t}{\rightarrow}X^0X0←sX1→tX0. Then despair started to sink in again when I thought about how that is an endomorphism and how to deal with its powers, i.e. compositions with itself?

But, Amar, thank you for removing my despair again with

Amar Hadzihasanovic said:

Then, yeah, a functor N→Span1(Set)\mathbb{N} \to \mathsf{Span}_1(\mathsf{Set})N→Span1​(Set) is determined by what the image of 111 is, and that's a directed graph. The image of nnn is the directed graph whose edges are length-nnn paths in the image of 111.

That sounds like it is definitely in the right direction for me :raised_hands:

John Baez said:

People don't usually say things like what you just said: they might say "a category whose objects are (A,B)-bimodules and whose morphisms are bimodule homomorphisms" for some algebras A and B...

You're right. Sorry. I really need to pin this down once and for all. All this time, I thought I was working with (A,A)(A,A)(A,A)-bimodules, but now I'm not so sure because AAA can be decomposed trivially into separate algebras, i.e.

A=⨁t∈ZAt.A = \bigoplus_{t\in\mathbb{Z}} A_t.A=⨁t∈Z​At​.

Each AtA_tAt​ is a commutative associative unital algebra with a prescribed basis etie^i_teti​ (coming from nodes of a directed graph) and unit element 1t=∑ieti1_t = \sum_{i} e^i_t1t​=∑i​eti​ so that the unit element of AAA is 1=⨁t1t.1 = \bigoplus_{t} 1_t.1=⨁t​1t​. The product is defined by how it acts on these basis elements, i.e.

(eti)(et′i′)=δi,i′δt,t′eti.(e^i_t) (e^{i'}_{t'}) = \delta^{i,i'} \delta_{t,t'} e^i_t.(eti​)(et′i′​)=δi,i′δt,t′​eti​.

I don't know if this decomposition is worth thinking about though :thinking:

If I do this, then I have (At,At+n)(A_t,A_{t+n})(At​,At+n​)-bimodules Ωn\Omega^nΩn that connect "nodes of AtA_tAt​" to "nodes of At+nA_{t+n}At+n​".

The algebra AtA_tAt​ can be interpretted as the algebra generated by the set of nodes at time ttt.

I need to think about this some more :thinking:

Dan Doel said:

Where does the name come from? Are the objects of the double category somehow considered to be fibrant? Like, is the promotion of an arrow to a proarrow like a lifting property?

A double category is fibrant, in this sense, if and only if the (source, target) functor D1→D0×D0D_1 \to D_0\times D_0D1​→D0​×D0​ is a Grothendieck fibration.
(And if and only if that same functor is an opfibration.)
That's in the original framed bicategories paper.

@Eric Forgy wrote:

. Sorry. I really need to pin this down once and for all. All this time, I thought I was working with (A,A)(A,A)(A,A)-bimodules, but now I'm not so sure because AAA can be decomposed trivially into separate algebras, i.e.

A=⨁t∈ZAt.A = \bigoplus_{t\in\mathbb{Z}} A_t.A=⨁t∈Z​At​.

Sounds like an (A,A)(A,A)(A,A)-bimodule will do just fine. If AAA breaks up as you suggest, then I bet you can use that to automatically break up any (A,A)(A,A)(A,A)-bimodule as you suggest - so those details are not something you need to carry around your neck all the time.
Oh, okay.

John Baez said:

Sounds like an (A,A)(A,A)(A,A)-bimodule will do just fine. If AAA breaks up as you suggest, then I bet you can use that to automatically break up any (A,A)(A,A)(A,A)-bimodule as you suggest - so those details are not something you need to carry around your neck all the time.

Cool. Thank you :pray:

If I am ok to stick with (A,A)(A,A)(A,A)-bimodules, then looking at:

John Baez said:

I just feel like adding that there's a super-important bicategory where:

  • objects are algebras over some field k,
  • morphisms from A to B are (A,B)-bimodules,
  • 2-morphisms are bimodule homomorphisms.

So here we aren't choosing a particular A and B: we're choosing all of them!

If I am only concerned with one algebra AAA, then I would have just one object and (A,A)(A,A)(A,A)-bimodules as endomorphisms, but AAA itself is trivially (I think) an (A,A)(A,A)(A,A)-bimodule, so I shifted this down one step with

  • Objects are (A,A)(A,A)(A,A)-bimodules (since AAA is an (A,A)(A,A)(A,A)-bimodule)
  • Morphisms are (A,A)(A,A)(A,A)-bimodule endomorphisms

More specifically, my category consists of (all objects are (A,A)(A,A)(A,A)-bimodules):

  • Objects A⊗KrA^{\otimes_K r}A⊗K​r: Tensor powers (over KKK) of AAA (a KKK-algebra)
  • Objects (Ω1)⊗Ar(\Omega^1)^{\otimes_A r}(Ω1)⊗A​r: Tensor powers (over AAA) of Ω1\Omega^1Ω1 (a subbimodule of A⊗KAA\otimes_K AA⊗K​A) (Note: I am pretty sure this must be coming from a span somewhere)
  • Objects Ωn\Omega^nΩn: Subbimodules of (Ω1)⊗An(\Omega^1)^{\otimes_A n}(Ω1)⊗A​n
  • Objects being various tensor products of the above
  • Morphisms being (A,A)(A,A)(A,A)-bimodule homomorphisms

The data to freely construct all of the above is contained in a directed graph (with possible restrictions, e.g. no loops, no cycles, so I'm thinking "directed acyclic graphs"). Putting all the pieces together seems too manual, so I am trying to find a clean and concise magical free functor. This isn't even the whole story because I also have daggers †\dagger† that reverse the direction of edges that let us define an inner product etc so I think I end up with some kind of Hilbert bimodule.

To explain a little more, we know there is a free functor

F:Alg→DiffAlg.F: \mathsf{Alg} \to \mathsf{DiffAlg}.F:Alg→DiffAlg.

A differential algebra freely constructed this way is "universal", i.e.

F(A)=(A,Ω~1,d~:A→Ω~1).F(A) = (A,\tilde\Omega^1,\tilde d: A\to\tilde\Omega^1).F(A)=(A,Ω~1,d~:A→Ω~1).

We also know (since d~:A→Ω~1\tilde d: A\to\tilde\Omega^1d~:A→Ω~1 is universal) that any other differential algebra (A,Ω1,d:A→Ω1)(A,\Omega^1,d: A\to\Omega^1)(A,Ω1,d:A→Ω1) factors through this one and there is a unique (A,A)(A,A)(A,A)-bimodule morphism

ϕ:Ω~1→Ω1\phi: \tilde\Omega^1\to\Omega^1ϕ:Ω~1→Ω1

with

d=ϕ∘d~.d = \phi \circ \tilde d.d=ϕ∘d~.

If AAA is generated from the vertices of a directed graph, then the (A,A)(A,A)(A,A)-bimodule morphism ϕ\phiϕ is generated from the "adjacency matrix" of the directed graph we call the "graph operator" G⊂A⊗KAG \subset A\otimes_K AG⊂A⊗K​A given by

G=∑i,jG(i,j)ei⊗KejG = \sum_{i,j} G(i,j) e^i\otimes_K e^jG=∑i,j​G(i,j)ei⊗K​ej

where G(i,j)=1G(i,j) = 1G(i,j)=1 if there is a directed edge i→ji\to ji→j and zero otherwise.

So to summarize, if I only give you a set of vertices, I can construct a "universal differential algebra" on that set which corresponds to the complete graph. To get another differential algebra besides the universal one, we need to set some of the directed edges to zero. That is captured by GGG so we need the full data of a directed graph to construct a general differential algebra.

Eric Forgy said:

To explain a little more, we know there is a free functor

F:Alg→DiffAlg.F: \mathsf{Alg} \to \mathsf{DiffAlg}.F:Alg→DiffAlg.

A differential algebra freely constructed this way is "universal", i.e.

F(A)=(A,Ω~1,d~:A→Ω~1).F(A) = (A,\tilde\Omega^1,\tilde d: A\to\tilde\Omega^1).F(A)=(A,Ω~1,d~:A→Ω~1).

That gunk just says you've got a differential ddd from your algebra to this AAA-module Ω~1\tilde\Omega^1Ω~1. It doesn't say anything about why this guy Ω~1\tilde\Omega^1Ω~1 is "universal". So I object to your use of the words "i.e." here: you're not actually explaining what's "universal" about it.

Yes, I'm nitpicking.. but you're in an audience of category theorists, who take universal properties seriously... so they'll wonder what universal property you're alluding to... and I just want to make it clear to them that you're not explaining that (and also you, in case you thought you were).

Sure :+1: I'll try to :pray:

What I'm talking about is spelled out in

  • Bourbaki's Elements of Mathematics, Algebra I, Chapter 3, Section 10.10, Universal problem for derivations : non-commutative case

and I fumbled around with it until I felt I understood it here (where I also pasted the relevant paragraphs from EoA).

In a nutshell, given an associative unital KKK-algebra AAA, Ω~1\tilde\Omega^1Ω~1 is the kernel of the product m:A⊗KA→Am: A\otimes_K A\to Am:A⊗K​A→A with m(a⊗Kb):=abm(a\otimes_K b) := abm(a⊗K​b):=ab, i.e. the product in AAA, and

d~:a↦1⊗Ka−a⊗K1\tilde d: a \mapsto 1\otimes_K a - a\otimes_K 1d~:a↦1⊗K​a−a⊗K​1

generates Ω~1\tilde\Omega^1Ω~1 as a left module (Proof is a couple lines in Bourbaki).

If ϕ:Ω~1→Ω1\phi: \tilde\Omega^1\to\Omega^1ϕ:Ω~1→Ω1 is an (A,A)(A,A)(A,A)-bimodule homomorphisms, then

d=ϕ∘d~:A→Ω1d = \phi\circ \tilde d: A\to\Omega^1d=ϕ∘d~:A→Ω1

is a derivation. So given ϕ\phiϕ, we get a derivation ddd.

Conversely, given a derivation d:A→Ω1d:A\to\Omega^1d:A→Ω1, since (x,y)↦x dy(x,y)\mapsto x\, dy(x,y)↦xdy is KKK-bilinear, there is a unique morphism ϕ:A⊗KA→Ω1\phi: A\otimes_K A\to\Omega^1ϕ:A⊗K​A→Ω1 given by ϕ(x⊗Ky)=x dy.\phi(x\otimes_K y) = x\,dy.ϕ(x⊗K​y)=xdy. This can be restricted to Ω~1\tilde\Omega^1Ω~1 so that given a derivation d:A→Ω1d:A\to\Omega^1d:A→Ω1, we obtain a unique (A,A)(A,A)(A,A)-bimodule homomorphism ϕ:Ω~1→Ω1\phi:\tilde\Omega^1\to\Omega^1ϕ:Ω~1→Ω1 and we have

Hom(A,A)(Ω~1,Ω1)≅DerK(A,Ω1).\mathsf{Hom}_{(A,A)}(\tilde\Omega^1,\Omega^1)\cong \mathsf{Der}_K(A,\Omega^1).Hom(A,A)​(Ω~1,Ω1)≅DerK​(A,Ω1).

What I'm doing is aplying this to the case where AAA is generated by vertices of a directed graph.

I am throwing in a bit of a twist though because if AAA is generated from vertices of a directed graph, we have Ω1\Omega^1Ω1 constructed from the adjacency of the directed graph as I mentioned above.

To see this, let

G~:=1⊗K1=∑i,jei⊗Kej\tilde G := 1\otimes_K 1 = \sum_{i,j} e^i\otimes_K e^jG~:=1⊗K​1=∑i,j​ei⊗K​ej

then

d~a:=[G~,a]=(1⊗K1)a−a(1⊗K1)=1⊗Ka−a⊗K1.\begin{aligned} \tilde d a :&= [\tilde G, a] \\ &= (1\otimes_K 1)a - a(1\otimes_K 1) \\ &= 1\otimes_K a - a\otimes_K 1.\end{aligned}d~a:​=[G~,a]=(1⊗K​1)a−a(1⊗K​1)=1⊗K​a−a⊗K​1.​

G~\tilde GG~ is a sum over all pairs of vertices and corresponds to a complete graph.

Now, let ϕ:Ω~1→Ω1\phi: \tilde\Omega^1\to\Omega^1ϕ:Ω~1→Ω1 be an (A,A)(A,A)(A,A)-bimodule homomorphism that simply maps some pairs (edges) ei⊗Keje^i\otimes_K e^jei⊗K​ej to zero, then we have our graph operator

G=ϕ(G~)=ϕ(1⊗K1)G = \phi(\tilde G) = \phi(1\otimes_K 1)G=ϕ(G~)=ϕ(1⊗K​1)

which gives rise to the unique derivation d:A→Ω1d: A\to\Omega^1d:A→Ω1 given by

d:a↦[G,a],d: a\mapsto [G,a],d:a↦[G,a],

which can also be written as

d=ϕ∘d~.d = \phi\circ \tilde d.d=ϕ∘d~.

(Note: If that :point_of_information: made any sense at all, I feel like I've gained some super powers :muscle: I've been thinking about this on and off for the last 20+ years and have never been able to state that much as succinctly before.)
Nice!

Amar Hadzihasanovic said:

Then, yeah, a functor N→Span1(Set)\mathbb{N} \to \mathsf{Span}_1(\mathsf{Set})N→Span1​(Set) is determined by what the image of 111 is, and that's a directed graph. The image of nnn is the directed graph whose edges are length-nnn paths in the image of 111.

I've never seen the functor

N→Span1(Set)\mathbb{N}\to\mathsf{Span_1(Set)}N→Span1​(Set)

before, but it looks pretty interesting. Does it have a name? Does it fit into any other interesting machinery?

But for the image of the morphism 111 to be a directed graph, wouldn't the domain category need to consist of two objects? :thinking:

If I understand (big "if"), N\mathbb{N}N has one object so it seems like the image of 111 would be a span S←S→SS\leftarrow S\rightarrow SS←S→S in Set.\mathsf{Set}.Set. :thinking:
An object in Span1(Set)\mathsf{Span}_1(\mathsf{Set})Span1​(Set) is a set SSS. A morphism from SSS to TTT is a pair of a set EEE and a span S←E→TS \leftarrow E \rightarrow TS←E→T.
So the image of the unique object ∙\bullet∙ of N\mathbb{N}N is a set SSS, and the image of the morphism 111 is an "endospan" S←E→SS \leftarrow E \rightarrow SS←E→S.
Which I think is what you want.
Yeah, but do SSS and EEE need to be in the image of the functor? If F(∙)=SF(\bullet) = SF(∙)=S, then where did EEE come from? :thinking:

The image of FFF in Span1(Set)\mathsf{Span_1(Set)}Span1​(Set) has just one object F(∙)=SF(\bullet) = SF(∙)=S so would F(1)F(1)F(1) be a span involving just one set, i.e. S←S→S?S\leftarrow S\rightarrow S?S←S→S?

It almost seems like the domain should be the monoid Z\mathbb{Z}Z plus one object ∙\bullet∙ such that ∙Z↦S\bullet_{\mathbb{Z}}\mapsto S∙Z​↦S, ∙↦E\bullet\mapsto E∙↦E and 1↦S←E→S.1\mapsto S\leftarrow E\rightarrow S.1↦S←E→S.
The other set EEE is part of the data of a morphism!
The fact that the domain of the functor has a single object just means that all morphisms in the image will have the same source and target.
I think you're getting confused by the fact that an endomorphism in the category of spans is given by the data of two functions which are not themselves endomorphisms in Set\mathsf{Set}Set.

That makes sense. Thank you :blush:

It feels a little weird that the image of a functor from a monoid has more than 1 object, but if we can consiser it part of the data of the morphism, then I think I'm ok with it :+1:

Amar Hadzihasanovic said:

I think you're getting confused by the fact that an endomorphism in the category of spans is given by the data of two functions which are not themselves endomorphisms in Set\mathsf{Set}Set.

That helps :+1:

I was actually ok with the idea that those two functions were part of the data and not endomorphisms so I should have also been fine with the idea that the other object EEE is also part of the data. Thanks for helping me see that :pray:

Back to my other question...

Does the functor

N→Span1(Set)\mathbb{N}\to\mathsf{Span_1(Set)}N→Span1​(Set)

have a name? Does it fit into any other interesting machinery (that I can read about)?

It is cool how F(1)F(1)F(1) is a directed graph and F(n)F(n)F(n) consists of "evolving paths of length n−1n-1n−1".

Where a directed edge (i,j)(i,j)(i,j) in F(1)F(1)F(1) has source s(i,j)=is(i,j) = is(i,j)=i and target t(i,j)=j,t(i,j) = j,t(i,j)=j, a 2-path (i,j,k)(i,j,k)(i,j,k) in F(2)F(2)F(2) has a source s(i,j,k)=(i,j)s(i,j,k) = (i,j)s(i,j,k)=(i,j) and a target t(i,j,k)=(j,k).t(i,j,k) = (j,k).t(i,j,k)=(j,k).
This is also nice because Span1(Set)\mathsf{Span_1(Set)}Span1​(Set) is a †\dagger†-category.

Eric Forgy said:

Does the functor

N→Span1(Set)\mathbb{N}\to\mathsf{Span_1(Set)}N→Span1​(Set)

have a name? Does it fit into any other interesting machinery (that I can read about)?

It isn't a unique functor, so there's no reason for it to have a special name..! Amar was pointing out that there is a correspondence between directed graphs and such functors, so you could call it "the functor FFF corresponding to the directed graph GGG"?

Yeah. I was just thinking. According to the nLab, a directed graph is already a functor

G:X→SetG: X\to \mathsf{Set}G:X→Set

but where XXX has two objects X0,X1X^0,X^1X0,X1 and two morphisms s,t:X1→X0s,t:X^1\to X^0s,t:X1→X0.

The functor

P:N→Span1(Set)P: \mathbb{N}\to\mathsf{Span_1(Set)}P:N→Span1​(Set)

seems at least as unique as that (and cooler) so I wouldn't be surprised if it had a name, but I also wouldn't be surprised if it doesn't have a name. I'm just curious :blush:

Anyway, thank you Amar :pray:

That functor gives me a lot to think about :blush:

The reason why one usually considers functors X→SetX \to \mathsf{Set}X→Set (in your notation) as directed graphs is that their natural transformations correspond to what people usually consider to be morphisms of graphs, namely, assignments of vertices to vertices and edges to edges that are compatible with source and target. That is, the functor category [X,Set][X, \mathsf{Set}][X,Set] “is” the category of directed graphs.
Whereas natural transformations of functors N→Span1(Set)\mathbb{N} \to \mathsf{Span}_1(\mathsf{Set})N→Span1​(Set) are a bit strange as a notion of morphism between directed graphs.

If I'm not mistaken, if you take two such functors corresponding to graphs G=(E,V)G = (E,V)G=(E,V) and G′=(E′,V′)G' = (E',V')G′=(E′,V′), a natural transformation between GGG and G′G'G′ may be pictured as a third, bipartite graph H=(F,V+V′)H = (F, V+V')H=(F,V+V′) where the source of each edge of HHH is a vertex of GGG and its target is a vertex of G′G'G′, with the property that there is a bijection between

  • paths (f,e′)(f, e')(f,e′) consisting of an edge of HHH followed by an edge of G′G'G′, and
  • paths (e,f′)(e, f')(e,f′) consisting of an edge of GGG followed by an edge of HHH.
So the functor category [N,Span1(Set)][\mathbb{N}, \mathsf{Span}_1(\mathsf{Set})][N,Span1​(Set)] is not the “usual” category of directed graphs.

Amar Hadzihasanovic said:

So the functor category [N,Span1(Set)][\mathbb{N}, \mathsf{Span}_1(\mathsf{Set})][N,Span1​(Set)] is not the “usual” category of directed graphs.

Oh. For sure :+1: Thanks for your note :pray:

This functor is definitely different, but I think it is cool :+1: If there is no existing name, I'd be tempted to call this functor (if the name wasn't already taken :tm: ) a "path space" and the functor category is the "category of path spaces". P(1)P(1)P(1) is a directed graph, i.e. 1-path space, and P(n)P(n)P(n) is an nnn-path space.

Replacing Set\mathsf{Set}Set with some other (special type of) category CCC, we have functors

N→Span1(C),\mathbb{N}\to \mathsf{Span_1}(C),N→Span1​(C),

which I might call a "path space in CCC" :thinking:

John Baez said:

Amar seemed to be saying it's the category of with sets as objects and spans of sets as morphisms. Is that all? That's usually called Span(Set)\mathsf{Span}(\mathsf{Set})Span(Set).

Yeah. Almost. From the nLab:

The 1-category of spans

Let CCC be a category with pullbacks and let Span1(C):=(Span(C))∼1\mathsf{Span_1}(C):=(\mathsf{Span}(C))_{∼1}Span1​(C):=(Span(C))∼1​ be the 1-category of objects of CCC and isomorphism class of spans between them as morphisms.

Then

Span1(C)\mathsf{Span}_1(C)Span1​(C) is a dagger category.

Next assume that CCC is a cartesian monoidal category. Then clearly Span1(C)\mathsf{Span}_1(C)Span1​(C) naturally becomes a monoidal category itself, but more: then

Span1(C)\mathsf{Span}_1(C)Span1​(C) is a dagger compact category.

Okay - yeah, when I said "it's the category of with sets as objects and spans of sets as morphisms" I really meant "it's the category of with sets as objects and isomorphism classes of spans of sets as morphisms."

I think the subscript 111 is only useful if you're talking both about the category and the bicategory and worried that people will mix them up... people don't usually do that; the nLab is just trying to be ultra-precise.
And even if you're talking about both, you have to say what the subscript 1 means, or nobody will guess.
Just sociology of mathematics here...

and extended linearly. However, these are not bimodule morphisms so they don't live in my category.

A⊗KA=FAlg∘P(1).A\otimes_K A = F_{\mathsf{Alg}}\circ P(1).A⊗K​A=FAlg​∘P(1).

(A⊗KA)⊗A(A⊗KA)=FAlg∘P(2)(A\otimes_K A) \otimes_A (A\otimes_K A) = F_{\mathsf{Alg}}\circ P(2)(A⊗K​A)⊗A​(A⊗K​A)=FAlg​∘P(2)

⋯\cdots⋯

I find this pretty complicated, but here's my instant reaction:

You are very interested in this thing:

d:A→Ω1~ d: A \to \tilde{\Omega^1}d:A→Ω1~

There's a category Vect→\mathsf{Vect}^\toVect→ where the objects are short chain complexes: pairs of vector spaces equipped with a linear map between them, like this:

d:V→W d : V \to Wd:V→W

I'm writing the linear map as ddd just to make you interested in it - in general it's just any linear map. Similarly, the phrase "short chain complex" is supposed to give you ideas about why we care about this, but it's just a name for two vector spaces and a linear map!

The category Vect→\mathsf{Vect}^\toVect→ is just the category where

  • objects are functors from →\to→ (the category with two objects and one non-identity morphism, which goes from one object to the other)
  • morphisms are natural transformations.

The category of graphs is very similar: it's Set⇒\mathsf{Set}^{\Rightarrow}Set⇒ where

  • objects are functors from ⇒\Rightarrow⇒ (the category with two objects and two non-identity morphisms, which goes from the first object to the second)
  • morphisms are natural transformations.

I would write ⇒\Rightarrow⇒ more beautifully if I easily could: it's supposed to be a picture of two objects and two morphisms going from the first object to the second! You're using some other name for this category.

There's an important functor

X:Set⇒→Vect→ X: \mathsf{Set}^{{\Rightarrow}} \to \mathsf{Vect}^{{\rightarrow}} X:Set⇒→Vect→

which takes a graph s,t:E→Vs,t: E \to Vs,t:E→V and turns it into a short chain complex. YOU KNOW THIS FUNCTOR - YOU'RE USING IT ALL THE TIME!

There's a lot more to say; people know a lot about this....

I'll just say one more thing: the functor XXX is equal to a more fundamental functor

Y:Set⇒→Vect⇒ Y: \mathsf{Set}^{{\Rightarrow}} \to \mathsf{Vect}^{{\Rightarrow}} Y:Set⇒→Vect⇒

composed with a functor

Z:Vect⇒→Vect→ Z: \mathsf{Vect}^{{\Rightarrow}} \to \mathsf{Vect}^{{\rightarrow}} Z:Vect⇒→Vect→
The stuff about algebras can also easily be worked into this story.

There's a lot more to say; people know a lot about this....

He's been involved in a lot of numerical methods stuff, I think. Here's a paper that's quicker to get ahold of:

  • Valtteri Lahtinen, P. Robert Kotiuga, Antti Stenvall, An electrical engineering perspective on missed opportunities in computational physics.

I haven't read it, but the grumbling tone of the title should appeal to you. Here's the abstract:

We look at computational physics from an electrical engineering perspective and suggest that several concepts of mathematics, not so well-established in computational physics literature, present themselves as opportunities in the field. We emphasize the virtues of the concept of elliptic complex and highlight the category theoretical background and its role as a unifying language between algebraic topology, differential geometry and modelling software design. In particular, the ubiquitous concept of naturality is central. We discuss the Galerkin finite element method as a way to achieve a discrete formulation and discuss its compatibility with so-called cochain methods. Despite the apparent differences in their underlying principles, in both one finds a finite-dimensional subcomplex of a cochain complex. From such a viewpoint, compatibility of a discretization boils down to preserving properties in such a process. Via reflection on the historical background and the identification of common structures, forward-looking research questions may be framed.

A quote from the first paragraph:

Through articulating physics via such concepts as natural differential operatorsand elliptic complexes, the framework of category theory provides a sense of synthesis to the seemingly scattered field. At first glance, the concepts of category theory may steer the reader’s thoughts towards foundations of mathematics. However, on a closer look, it is also the glue and common ground throughout computational physics.

Yes. The finite element method has some tantalizing mimectic properties, but you definitely lose the algebraic characteristics as currently formulated. Discrete differential geometry (as formulated by Urs and I) maintain this.
You should definitely talk to Robert, since either he will convince you that your ideas are already known, or he'll get excited to hear about them.

Sounds good.

Alain who? Connes?
Alain Bossavit
(I didn't really think you were hanging out with Alain Connes.)

Bossavit was a pioneer in computational electromagnetics focusing on topological aspects. Mainly the nilpotency of ddd and the duality via Stokes' theorem with the boundary map ∂\partial∂, which translates to conservation of charge among other things. Naive discretizations do not necessarily satisfy d2=0.d^2=0.d2=0. However, it is generally assumed that you can't maintain the algebraic aspects, but I never accepted that. Discrete differential geometry insists that we work with associative DGAs (Wilson's DGAs are not associative on cochains).

Finitary associative DGAs are noncommutative (but noncommutative in a cool way). Finitary commutative DGAs are nonassociative. Only in the continuum limit do associative DGAs become commutative (like a classical limit in QM).

That's cool. Of course there are plenty of finite-dimensional (super)commutative associative DGAs, but I guess they don't do what you want. It could be nice for the theorem-proving crowd to make that into a theorem, by turning "what you want" into some precise hypotheses. (Maybe you've already done it.)
